{include "affiliate_loader"} The Missouri General Assembly is piling on egregious legislation to take rights away from our LGBTQ+ community. It is the responsibility of all of us to fight back. Here's how. {include "pre-header-spacing"} {beacon}

{include "default_salutation"} –

As a Missourian, you hold power to fight back against legislation that could take rights away from our LGBTQ+ neighbors. First, I want to tell you about the bills we're facing this week. Then, I'm going to tell you what you can do about it.

The Bills:

HB2173 (possibly the nation's most bizarre anti-LGBTQ bill in 2020) seeks to strip the marriage rights of all people. All marriages will become domestic unions. This could take marriage equality away from same-sex couples.

HRJ 82 and SJR 50 propose to create a statewide vote to ban transgender high school athletes from gendered sports teams.

Please be aware there are 15 anti-LGBT bills currently up for consideration in the Missouri Legislature. We have the second-highest number of anti-LGBT in the country.

We will keep you posted throughout the process, but here is what you can do TODAY.

Stop HJR 82, the proposed constitutional amendment that would keep trans kids from participating in sports. Call 1-314-710-2258 to be connected to the General Laws Committee and urge them to vote "NO" on this discriminatory resolution. Visit our website, to learn more.

Join Us In Person

We are hosting trans community teach-ins across the state. The events will feature performances to uplift, words from local trans/GNC, and LGBTQ leaders – and info on how you can help fight these bills.

  • Kansas City, Thursday, February 20, 6 – 8 p.m. at the SEIU Local 2 Building, 4526 The Paseo
  • Columbia, Saturday, February 22, 5 – 7 p.m., Fretboard Coffee, 1013 E. Walnut Street
  • Springfield, Sunday, February 23, 3 – 5 p.m., MSU Welcome Center, 1148 Bear Boulevard

It is time to take action. You have a voice in this process, and it is time to make it heard. Fight like your civil liberties depend on it – because they do.

Sincerely,

Sara Baker
Policy Director, ACLU of {affiliate_name}
